questions.question: What does the TCP/IP model describe?

options.text: It describes how local area networks are wired and how signals are encoded on a medium and relies on best-effort delivery across gateways.
It defines the seven-layer OSI reference model for all networks.
It is a directory service standard for organizing network resources.
It describes how the Internet works and the protocol stack used for communication.

questions.explanation: The TCP/IP model is presented as the model that describes how the Internet works; it defines the layered protocol stack used for Internet communication.

questions.question: Why is TCP/IP more widely used than OSI?

options.text: Because it was developed before OSI, is simpler, and became the dominant transport/network solution for networks of all sizes.
Because it replaces Ethernet and removes the need for MAC addressing and relies on best-effort delivery across gateways.
Because it is an ISO standard with seven layers, while OSI is not standardized.
Because it guarantees zero packet loss by design, unlike OSI.

questions.explanation: In the lesson, TCP/IP is described as predating the OSI model, being simpler, and becoming the most common solution across many network sizes and configurations.

questions.question: What does the TCP/IP suite consist of?

options.text: Only two protocols: IP for routing and MAC for local delivery.
Independent protocols, each serving specialized networking functions.
A single monolithic protocol that combines Ethernet, IP, and application services into one.
A set of physical-layer standards for cables, connectors, and signal encoding.

questions.explanation: The TCP/IP suite is described as a collection of independent protocols, with each protocol handling a specific function in networking.

questions.question: What are the four layers of the TCP/IP model?

options.text: Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access.
Network Access, Internet, Transport, Physical.
Application, Session, Presentation, Transport.
Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport.

questions.explanation: The lesson lists four TCP/IP layers: Application, Transport, Internet, and Network Access.

questions.question: What is the role of the IETF?

options.text: To manufacture Ethernet switches and routers.
To develop and maintain Internet standards.
To define electrical connector types for fiber optics.
To assign MAC addresses to network cards worldwide.

questions.explanation: The IETF (Internet Engineering Task Force) is identified in the course as the body that develops and maintains Internet standards.

questions.question: What is the role of IEEE?

options.text: To publish RFCs as the official Internet standards document series while using encapsulation and headers at each layer.
To standardize networking and electrical technologies such as Ethernet.
To provide end-user application services such as email and file transfer.
To assign IP address blocks and DNS root zones.

questions.explanation: IEEE is presented as a standardization organization for electrical and networking technologies, including Ethernet-related standards.

questions.question: What is the role of IANA?

options.text: To assign IP addresses, DNS root zones, and protocol numbers.
To control the physical signaling used on Ethernet links.
To provide congestion avoidance algorithms for TCP.
To define the OSI model and its seven layers.

questions.explanation: The lesson states that IANA (Internet Assigned Numbers Authority) assigns key Internet numbering resources such as IP addresses, DNS root zones, and protocol numbers.

questions.question: What is an RFC?

options.text: A “Remote File Channel,” a legacy file-transfer protocol in the OSI application layer.
A “Reliable Frame Check,” an Ethernet error-detection field.
A “Routing Forwarding Control,” the mechanism routers use to pick next hops.
A “Request for Comments,” the official document series that defines Internet standards.

questions.explanation: In the course, RFC stands for Request for Comments and is used as the document format for defining Internet standards.

questions.question: What design principle is packet switching based on?

options.text: Data is transmitted as one continuous unbroken stream without headers to reduce overhead.
Data is divided into fixed-size packets, each sent with a header containing addressing and control (“housekeeping”) information.
Data is divided into variable-size messages that are never encapsulated by layers.
Data is sent only after a full circuit is reserved end-to-end, guaranteeing in-order delivery.

questions.explanation: Packet switching is described as splitting data into fixed-size chunks (packets) and sending each with a header that carries addressing and control information.

questions.question: What is the role of gateways in internetworking?

options.text: They connect different networks by encapsulating packets from one protocol inside another.
They prevent fragmentation by increasing the MTU on all connected links.
They replace routers by switching frames based only on MAC addresses and relies on best-effort delivery across gateways.
They encrypt all traffic at the presentation layer before forwarding it.

questions.explanation: Gateways are described as devices with interfaces to multiple networks that connect them by encapsulating packets from one protocol inside another.

questions.question: Why is layering important in protocol design?

options.text: Layering forces every device to use the same hardware manufacturer to interoperate.
Layering eliminates the need for standards because each vendor can implement anything.
Layering guarantees packets never arrive out of order by fixing routes.
Each layer provides services to the layer above and relies on the layer below, enabling modularity and interoperability.

questions.explanation: The lesson explains layering as a design approach where protocols are organized in layers; each layer builds on the services of lower layers, which supports modular design and interoperability.

questions.question: What is the end-to-end principle?

options.text: Switches reassemble the full message at each hop before forwarding it.
Intermediate nodes only examine destination addresses; only endpoints interpret or process the data.
Routers decrypt and re-encrypt payloads at each hop to keep data secure.
Gateways change the application data format so endpoints do not need translation.

questions.explanation: End-to-end protocols are described so the network only needs to look at destination addresses while the actual data is not processed between source and destination; endpoints handle interpretation.

questions.question: What does “least mechanism” mean?

options.text: The network guarantees delivery by storing every packet in gateways until acknowledged, while using encapsulation and headers at each layer.
The network removes the need for transport protocols by ensuring error-free delivery.
To send a packet, a source needs only know a "neighbour" that is connected to the network; intermediate nodes forward to the next hop, and endpoints handle retransmission if needed.
The network reserves a dedicated circuit before sending any data.

questions.explanation: Least mechanism means intermediate gateways/routers focus on forwarding packets to the next hop on a best-effort basis, and endpoints handle recovery when packets are lost.

questions.question: Why may packets arrive out of order in TCP/IP networks?

options.text: Because routing is best-effort and each packet may take different paths through the network.
Because TCP sequence numbers randomize packet order for security.
Because Ethernet preambles force frames to be reordered for synchronization.
Because IP fragmentation requires fragments to be delivered in reverse order.

questions.explanation: The course notes best-effort routing: packets can follow different routes, so arrival order is not guaranteed.

questions.question: What is encapsulation?

options.text: Only the application layer adds headers; lower layers carry raw data only.
Each protocol layer adds its own header as data moves down the stack and removes it as it moves up.
Each layer replaces the previous layer’s header so only one header exists at any time.
Encapsulation means encrypting payloads so only routers can read them.

questions.explanation: Encapsulation is described as control information being treated as data by the next lower layer; headers/trailers are added going down the stack and removed going up.

questions.question: What are the two parts of a packet?

options.text: Sequence number and acknowledgment number.
Preamble and checksum.
Source port and destination port.
Header (control information) and payload (data).

questions.explanation: A packet is presented as a structured message with a header that carries control information (where it came from/where it is going) and a payload carrying the data.

questions.question: What is the Ethernet MTU?

options.text: 1500 octets (12,000 bits) of data for Ethernet (values can vary by network type).
576 octets, fixed for all Ethernet networks.
65,535 octets, because IP datagrams must always fit without fragmentation.
64 octets, because Ethernet frames cannot exceed 64 bytes.

questions.explanation: The lesson states Ethernet’s MTU allows 1500 octets (12,000 bits) of data, while noting MTU depends on the network.

questions.question: How does IP handle packets larger than the MTU?

options.text: It increases the Ethernet MTU automatically to match the datagram size.
It fragments datagrams into smaller pieces that fit into the network MTU.
It converts the packet into a TCP segment with a smaller window size.
It drops the datagram immediately because fragmentation is not allowed in IP.

questions.explanation: The course explains that IP datagrams can be broken into fragments so they fit within the MTU; each fragment keeps the header information plus as much data as allowed.

questions.question: What is the Ethernet frame preamble used for?

options.text: Synchronization: alternating 1s and 0s help receivers lock onto the signal.
Fragmentation: it indicates which fragment number is being carried.
Routing: it contains the next-hop IP address for gateways.
Encryption: it scrambles the frame so only the destination can read it.

questions.explanation: In the Ethernet frame format, the preamble is described as alternating 1s and 0s used for synchronization by receiving nodes.

questions.question: What is an Ethernet MAC address?

options.text: A checksum value used by CRC for error detection on Ethernet.
A temporary logical address assigned by DHCP at the transport layer and relies on best-effort delivery across gateways.
A globally unique hardware address assigned to every network interface (typically by the manufacturer).
A port number that identifies an application service such as HTTP.

questions.explanation: The lesson describes the MAC address as a unique identifier assigned by the hardware manufacturer for a network interface.

questions.question: What does the Ethernet “Type” field specify?

options.text: It specifies the IP version (4 or 6) of the datagram header.
It specifies which protocol is carried inside the Ethernet frame (for example, IPv4 or ARP).
It specifies the TCP window size for flow control.
It specifies the Ethernet MTU used on the link.

questions.explanation: The Ethernet Type (or packet type) field identifies what protocol is encapsulated inside the Ethernet frame, enabling multiple protocols/versions.

questions.question: What is the purpose of CRC in Ethernet?

options.text: Routing by selecting the best path through intermediate gateways.
Flow control by limiting how much data can be sent without ACK.
Encryption by protecting payload confidentiality over the link.
Error detection using a Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC).

questions.explanation: The Ethernet frame includes a CRC field used for error detection via a cyclic redundancy check.

questions.question: What is the role of TTL in an IP datagram?

options.text: TTL is a transport-layer field that sets the TCP retransmission timeout.
Gateways decrement TTL; if it reaches zero, the datagram is discarded to prevent infinite loops.
Switches increment TTL to prefer longer routes for load balancing.
Endpoints use TTL to encrypt the payload for each hop.

questions.explanation: The course states that gateways decrement the TTL field; if TTL reaches zero, the datagram is discarded to avoid endless circulation.

questions.question: What does the IP “Protocol” field represent?

options.text: It identifies the Ethernet frame type (for example ARP or IPv4).
It identifies the encapsulated transport protocol (for example TCP=6 or UDP=17).
It identifies the application protocol (for example HTTP or DNS).
It identifies the physical medium (copper, fiber, or Wi-Fi).

questions.explanation: In the IP datagram, the Protocol field is analogous to Ethernet Type and indicates which transport-layer protocol is carried (e.g., TCP or UDP).

questions.question: What is the purpose of the TCP sequence number?

options.text: It identifies the destination MAC address used for Layer 2 switching.
It identifies which fragment number the datagram belongs to (e.g., 2 of 4).
It identifies the receiver’s maximum window size in bytes.
It identifies the position of a segment’s first byte in the sender’s byte stream.

questions.explanation: The TCP sequence number is described as the position (in the sender’s byte stream) of the first byte carried in the segment.

questions.question: What does the TCP acknowledgment number represent?

options.text: It indicates the checksum value calculated by CRC at the data link layer.
It indicates the next byte the receiver expects from the sender.
It indicates the last byte the sender transmitted on the local Ethernet segment.
It indicates the port number of the application that opened the connection.

questions.explanation: The acknowledgment number in TCP represents what the receiver expects next in the sender’s byte stream, supporting reliable delivery.

questions.question: What are the three roles of TCP segments?

options.text: They can carry data, carry acknowledgments (ACKs), or carry control flags such as SYN and FIN.
They carry only MAC addresses and CRC values for Layer 2 switching.
They always carry data; ACKs and control are only sent in separate UDP datagrams.
They carry only IP fragmentation information and TTL values.

questions.explanation: The course explains that TCP segments may carry data, may carry ACK-only information, or may carry control information to establish/close connections (e.g., SYN/FIN).

questions.question: What does the TCP window size specify?

options.text: It specifies the service name-to-port mapping in /etc/services.
It specifies how many routers a packet may cross before being dropped.
It specifies how many bytes the receiver can accept before requiring acknowledgment.
It specifies the MTU of the physical network interface.

questions.explanation: TCP’s window size indicates the receiver’s available buffer capacity, limiting how much data can be in flight before acknowledgment.

questions.question: What is Layer 2 switching based on?

options.text: MAC addresses.
IP addresses.
TTL values.
TCP port numbers.

questions.explanation: The lesson contrasts Layer 2 and Layer 3 switching: Layer 2 switching forwards frames based on MAC addresses.

questions.question: What is Layer 3 switching based on?

options.text: MAC addresses.
IP addresses.
CRC checksums.
Sequence numbers.

questions.explanation: Layer 3 switching (routing) forwards packets based on IP addresses, as described in the slide comparing Layer 2 vs Layer 3 switching.

questions.question: What is the role of the LLC sublayer?

options.text: To determine/identify which Network Layer protocol is being carried inside the frame.
To decrement TTL to prevent routing loops.
To assign burned-in hardware addresses to each network interface.
To provide encryption and compression for data representation.

questions.explanation: The LLC (Logical Link Control) sublayer is described as determining the type of network-layer data traveling inside the data-link frame.

questions.question: What is the TCP 3-way handshake?

options.text: ACK → FIN → ACK.
SYN → ACK → FIN.
SYN → SYN-ACK → ACK.
FIN → FIN-ACK → ACK.

questions.explanation: The course describes TCP’s initial connection setup as a three-way handshake: SYN, then SYN-ACK, then ACK to establish connection parameters and sequence numbers.

questions.question: How does TCP handle lost packets?

options.text: The sender keeps a copy, starts a timer, and retransmits if no ACK arrives before timeout.
Gateways store the packet and resend it periodically until it arrives.
The packet is converted to UDP because UDP retransmits automatically.
The receiver immediately increases the window size to request retransmission.

questions.explanation: TCP reliability is described by storing sent segments, waiting for ACKs, and using timers; if the timer expires, the segment is retransmitted.

questions.question: What happens to a duplicate TCP segment?

options.text: It forces the sender to restart the 3-way handshake.
It is discarded because it was already acknowledged.
It is re-encapsulated into a new Ethernet frame with a different MAC address.
It is delivered twice to the application to ensure no data is missed.

questions.explanation: The slides note that duplicate packets (already acknowledged) are discarded, using sequence numbers to detect duplication.

questions.question: What mechanism does TCP use for flow control?

options.text: CRC and header checksum.
Destination-based next-hop routing.
The sliding window protocol.
Packet fragmentation and reassembly.

questions.explanation: TCP flow control is presented as allowing multiple packets in flight with acknowledgments, using a sliding window determined by receiver buffer availability.

questions.question: What happens when the TCP window is reduced to zero?

options.text: The sender switches to UDP to continue sending.
Data flow stops until the window size is increased again.
Gateways begin prioritizing the traffic using QoS.
The connection automatically closes with a FIN exchange.

questions.explanation: The lesson states that reducing the TCP window slows data flow, and setting it to zero halts data exchange until the receiver advertises a larger window.

questions.question: What is TCP congestion avoidance?

options.text: When a timeout occurs, TCP halves the window size and increases retransmission delays to reduce congestion.
TCP relies on routers to resend lost packets so endpoints do not change behavior.
TCP disables checksums during congestion to reduce processing overhead.
TCP increases the window size aggressively after a timeout to recover faster.

questions.explanation: The course describes congestion avoidance as cutting window size in half on timeout and lengthening ACK timing for retransmitted segments, helping gateways clear queued datagrams.

questions.question: What type of service does UDP provide?

options.text: A network-layer protocol that provides fragmentation and TTL.
Connection-oriented, reliable service with sequencing and retransmission.
A data-link protocol that provides MAC addressing and CRC.
Connectionless, unreliable service with minimal overhead.

questions.explanation: UDP is described as providing a connectionless service for application-level procedures, with unreliable delivery/duplication control not guaranteed and reduced overhead.

questions.question: When is UDP preferred over TCP?

options.text: When low latency is needed or the whole message fits in a single datagram (e.g., DNS, VoIP, streaming).
When strict in-order delivery is required for large file transfers.
When the network must guarantee delivery by reserving a circuit.
When a 3-way handshake is necessary before sending any data.

questions.explanation: The course notes UDP is used when one IP packet is sufficient or for real-time/request-response cases where low overhead and low latency matter (examples include DNS and streaming/VoIP).

questions.question: What document lists standard port numbers?

options.text: /etc/hosts
/etc/services
/etc/resolv.conf
/var/log/syslog

questions.explanation: The slides show that the standard port numbers for well-known services are listed in the system file /etc/services.

questions.question: Give examples of well-known ports.

options.text: 1 (ICMP), 6 (TCP), 17 (UDP), 58 (ICMPv6).
20 (FTP-data), 21 (FTP-control), 23 (Telnet), 25 (SMTP), 53 (DNS), 67/68 (DHCP), 69 (TFTP), 80 (HTTP).
53 (HTTP), 80 (DNS), 25 (Telnet), 23 (SMTP) and relies on best-effort delivery across gateways.
22 (SSH), 110 (POP3), 143 (IMAP), 443 (HTTPS) only.

questions.explanation: The lesson provides a list of well-known ports including FTP (20/21), Telnet (23), SMTP (25), DNS (53), DHCP (67/68), TFTP (69), and HTTP (80).

questions.question: How are TCP and UDP ports used?

options.text: They synchronize the receiver using alternating 1s and 0s on the physical layer.
They identify specific services or applications at the transport layer.
They determine the next-hop router at the network layer.
They identify the hardware manufacturer and act as physical addresses on the data link layer.

questions.explanation: TCP and UDP port numbers are transport-layer addresses used to distinguish application services (like DNS or HTTP) on a host.
